data.title: What to see in Covadonga in one day with children
data.meta_description: Covadonga is an ideal place to visit as a family, alone or as a couple with multiple activities for all tastes, preferences or needs. With an idyllic natural environment, it is the perfect option to visit the north of the Iberian Peninsula if you don't have much time. One day could be enough to explore this Asturian gem, which has an outstanding historical and cultural heritage worth visiting at least once in your life.
data.text:
Covadonga is in the heart of Asturias. It's a place where history, spirituality and nature come together to offer a unique experience. This destination captures the essence of Asturias, with its cultural and natural wealth, and invites you to discover its hidden treasures. Its stunning natural surroundings are worth visiting at any time of the year, whether as a family, solo traveller or couple.

Explore Covadonga in one day

If you only have one day to visit Covadonga, expect a day full of natural wonders and cultural heritage.

The Covadonga Lakes are nestled in the heart of the Picos de Europa National Park – a place where nature is at its most unspoilt.

Lakes Enol and Ercina, surrounded by imposing mountains and green meadows, are ideal for hiking, taking dreamy photographs and enjoying nature.

When planning your day in Covadonga, don't forget to include a visit to the Holy Cave, where you can feel the spirituality that emanates from this sacred place.

The Basilica of Santa María la Real will impress you with its neo-Romanesque style.

And if you have time, visit the Museum of the Royal Site of Covadonga to discover the history and legends that have made this enclave a symbol of Asturian identity.

Visiting Covadonga with children

Exploring Covadonga with children is an adventure that promises to be as educational as it is exciting.

Covadonga's natural environment provides a unique opportunity for children to learn about the local flora and fauna while enjoying the great outdoors.

You can plan a child-friendly walk where they can marvel at the views and be able to play in the rolling meadows.

Don't miss the chance to visit the Holy Cave with them – telling them the story of Don Pelayo and the Virgin of Covadonga can be an unforgettable experience.

And for a touch of fun and education, the Museum of the Royal Site has exhibitions that will interest them and learn more about Asturian culture and traditions.

What to eat in Covadonga?

The cuisine of Covadonga is excellent and famous throughout Spain. This part of Asturias offers a delicious combination of flavours that reflect the region's natural and cultural wealth. Must-try dishes include fabada asturiana, a hearty bean stew with sausages such as chorizo and black pudding; cabrales cheese, a strong blue cheese that is a sensory experience; and cachopo, breaded and fried veal fillets stuffed with ham and cheese. To sweeten your palate, the frixuelos and rice pudding are traditional desserts that will leave you with fond memories of your visit.

Cider, the symbolic drink of Asturias, is the perfect accompaniment to any meal, and at Covadonga, you can enjoy it at its best. Make sure you try your hand at the escanciado ritual – pouring the cider from above so that it is aerated when it hits the glass, releasing all its aromas. Without a doubt, food is a fundamental aspect of discovering Covadonga and the surrounding area.

How to get to Covadonga

Getting to Covadonga is easy and it can be done in different ways, depending on your starting point and preferences. Below, you will find a number of options so that you can choose the one that best suits your needs:

Car: If you prefer the freedom of travelling by car, you will find that Covadonga is well connected by road. From Oviedo, the capital of the Principality of Asturias, you can take the A-64 and then the AS-114 to reach Cangas de Onís, where you can follow the signs to Covadonga. This route will allow you to enjoy the Asturian countryside.

Bus: There are regular bus services from the main Asturian cities to Cangas de Onís. Once there, you can take a local bus that will take you directly to Covadonga. This option is ideal if you don't want to worry about parking or if you're looking for a more sustainable alternative.

Train: Although there is no train station in Covadonga, you can arrive by train to Oviedo or Gijón and then take a bus or rent a car to complete your trip to Covadonga.

Plane: The closest airport to Covadonga is Asturias airport, located in Santiago del Monte, near Avilés. From the airport, you can hire a car or take a bus to Oviedo and continue your journey to Covadonga as described above.

Living in Covadonga

Covadonga is an interesting place to call home. This Asturian enclave, renowned for its natural landscapes and its historical and spiritual importance, offers a unique quality of life for those seeking peace and tranquillity amid nature. Living in Covadonga means waking up every day to stunning scenery, and views of the Picos de Europa Mountains and having the chance to explore its rich culture and traditions.
